description:
Obesity can increase the risk of many other diseases, including diabetes, high blood pressure, and high cholestrol, as well as heart disease, and stroke. In some cases, unexplained weight change may also be indicative of underlying conditions such as thyroid disorder.

All individuals 18 years of age or older should monitor their **BMI** or **waist circumference** on an annual basis.

descriptionHTML:
All normal risk, asymptomatic women 50 to 69 years of age should be screened with **mammography** only, every 2 years.

Women in high-risk groups are recommended to undergo **MRI breast** annually in addition to **mammograms**. In such cases, mammogram screening should still be performed as some cancers may manifest as micro-calcifications which may not be shown on MRI.
riskGroups: Carriers of BRCA1, BRCA2, PALB2, or other high-risk gene mutations
Previous history of chest radiation therapy

descriptionHTML:
All women who have ever had sexual intercourse should undergo screening for cervical cancer from the age of 25.

Women aged 25 to 29 years should be screened with the **Pap smear**, at least once every 3 years. **HPV testing** is not recommended for women from the age of 25 to 29.

Women aged 30 years and above should be screened with **HPV testing**. This should be performed at least once every 5 years.

For average-risk individuals, screening for colorectal cancer should begin at 50 years.

Screening with **stool analysis (FIT)** should be performed annually, or screening with **colonoscopy** should be performed every 5 to 10 years.

Individuals in higher-risk groups are recommended to undergo **colonoscopy** earlier and more frequently.

Screening should begin at age 40 years, and be considered in adults of any age if any of the risk factors for diabetes is present.

Relevant tests include **fasting blood glucose** or **glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c)**.
riskGroups: Women who have delivered a baby 4 kg or more; or previously diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus
Low levels of HDL cholesterol and/or high triglyceride level

descriptionHTML:
Screening should be carried out in all individuals aged 40 years and above. It is recommended that clinicians routinely screen younger adults (men and women aged 18 and older) for lipid disorders including high cholestrol if they have other risk factors for coronary artery disease (CAD).

Relevant tests include the **fasting lipids test** or **non-fasting lipids test**.
riskGroups: Pre-existing CAD, cerebrovascular or peripheral artery disease
Aged 18 years and above who have other risk factors for CAD

descriptionHTML:
Periodic screening for high blood pressure is recommended for all adults aged 18 years or older.

Screening is performed with **blood pressure measurement**.
